parent_formation: British 8th Army (reinforced as New Zealand Corps for Mareth operation)

commander.name: Lieutenant-General Bernard Cyril Freyberg VC
commander.previous_service: Commander 2nd NZ Expeditionary Force since 1939, led El Alamein assault, Victoria Cross (WWI)

artillery.note: Reinforced artillery for Mareth assault. New 17-pounder AT guns deployed.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Increased vehicle count (6,000 total) for Left Hook mobile operation through Matmata Hills

supply_logistics.supply_status: EXCELLENT - Major supply buildup for Mareth offensive. Montgomery quadrupled strength at Mareth (400 tanks, 500 AT guns across 8th Army). NZ Corps reinforced for Left Hook maneuver. Extended supply lines from Tripoli (captured 23 Jan) to Mareth front.
notes: Left Hook mobile operation required massive fuel/ammo stockpile
6,000 vehicles required extensive logistics support
Montgomery's supply buildup (Feb 26 - Mar 18) crucial to success
Tripoli port provides main supply base

weather_environment.terrain_type: Southern Tunisia - Matmata Hills, Tebaga Gap, Jebel Dahar mountains. Challenging terrain for armored/mobile operations. Rocky hills, narrow gaps, desert lowlands.
notes: Matmata Hills difficult terrain - rocky, mountainous
Tebaga Gap narrow passage for Left Hook
Desert lowlands beyond Mareth Line
Spring weather improving for mobile operations

subordinate_units.note: Equipped with Sherman tanks since October 1942
2,500 Senegalese troops attached for Left Hook operation
Greek commando company attached to NZ Corps

tactical_doctrine.role: Reinforced as New Zealand Corps for 'Left Hook' outflanking maneuver around Mareth Line defenses through Matmata Hills and Tebaga Gap. Mobile armored/mechanized force to bypass Axis fortifications.
special_capabilities: Veteran division - continuous combat since Greece 1941
Combined arms excellence (infantry, armor, artillery coordination)
Left Hook maneuver - strategic outflanking movement
known_issues: Difficult terrain in Matmata Hills (rocky, narrow gaps)
Extended supply lines for mobile operation
Lost 945 men during Left Hook / Mareth battles

major_battles: Battle of Mareth Line - Left Hook operation (18-30 March 1943): 945 casualties, 51 tanks lost
notes: Division reinforced and renamed New Zealand Corps for Mareth operation
Left Hook maneuver through Matmata Hills/Tebaga Gap forced Axis withdrawal from Mareth Line
Montgomery message 30 March: 'My very best congratulations to NZ Corps... left hook led to complete disintegration of enemy resistance'
French (2,500 Senegalese) and Greek Sacred Band attached
Operation launched 18 March with 6,000 vehicles
Success led to Axis retreat from southern Tunisia

source: WebSearch: 2nd New Zealand Division Mareth Line March 1943
Wikipedia - Battle of the Mareth Line
known_gaps: Exact vehicle breakdown estimated from 6,000 total
French force composition (2,500 Senegalese) limited details
notes: Q1 1943: Division at MARETH LINE (Southern Tunisia)
Major operations: Left Hook outflanking maneuver (18-30 March 1943)
Division reinforced as New Zealand Corps with French and Greek forces
Casualties: 945 men, 51 tanks lost in March
Terrain: Matmata Hills, Tebaga Gap (mountainous, not desert)
Tier 2 classification due to estimated vehicle breakdown and missing commander names
Used 1942-Q4 baseline with Mareth 1943-Q1 delta changes

primary_sources: WebSearch - Wikipedia Battle of Mareth Line
known_gaps: Vehicle breakdown estimated from 6,000 total count
French and Greek force details limited
